messages.content: Solidity has blockhash function, that allows to get blockhash of one of the last 256 blocks. Do o1js have something like it?
You can set precondition to get protocol state hash
I want to get previous blockHash. For example current block is 100, I want to get hash for block 90, not for current one
Current block hash includes the previous ones
Current hash is single value. I need exact value of hash on exact block. Like blockhash in solidity
I don't get what you mean. You can use a proof to show that the hash X blocks ago is Y with public input being current block hash Z.
I need hash of exact block on chain. Proof of it is not ideal, beacuse it will quite often fail due to preconditions. Solidity blockhash  would be ideal for my case
Yes, that is the fundamental issue.
You can however do it in two turns.
First transaction witnesses the block hash _without proofs possibly_, and possibly without doing anything at all. Proof-less, signature-less account update, but has a precondition on block hash.
I'm not sure what the exact precondition is but there's some network precondition for this.
The next transaction, with an account update on the same account, uses the _receipt chain hash_ to verify that this precondition did indeed succeed in the past.
That should be enough.

You can do it without receipt chain hash too if you add a proof to the first transaction, but that makes it slower and more likely to fail, and more likely for you to pay a fee on a failed transaction.

OTOH if it did not need a proof, someone else could also use the account in their own transaction and mess with the receipt chain hash, so perhaps it's unavoidable to have a small proof on the first one.
The proof could enforce that you push it as an action.

Two step process could be a solution. First transaction still have a chance to fail, however it will be generated quicker, so chance will be lower. And second transaction will always succeed

Thanks

Ok, I have started to implement it.

What I need: given the hash of block B, prove hash of block A(A created prior to B originally). 

How I am thinking to implement it: get all block of proofs from block A to B, and via recursive proof prove A -> B

For doing so I need
1) Proof for exact block. I found Graphql field  for it https://github.com/MinaProtocol/mina/blob/3ba67430251d36622086183fdcbac464d4603c56/graphql_schema.json#L9914
2) BlockProof class. Where I can find it, to pass BlockProof to my proof?

embeds.title: mina/graphql_schema.json at 3ba67430251d36622086183fdcbac464d4603c5...
embeds.description: Mina is a cryptocurrency protocol with a constant size blockchain, improving scaling while maintaining decentralization and security. - MinaProtocol/mina

messages.content:
You want to prove that X -> ... -> Y, where X is the prior block hash that you want to access, and Y is the block hash that has been witnessed, either by prior transaction or by current precondition.

You don't need block proof for that, just the protocol states for each block in between X and Y.
We discussed it with o1js team. For this blockBodyHash is enough to recreate MerkleList for block hash. But it is not provided in current version on GraphQL
But blockproof is also not an option, because we can't check, if this blockproof related to current chain or to the orphan one
Just listen to network
Wdym orphan
Blocks that are produced, but do not belong to the main chain
How? Graphql do not provide enough data
Operate own node?
I don’t get what you mean by this honestly

For example check this two blocks 
https://minascan.io/mainnet/block/3NKN6sgezWyJZp6awqtmjSwHWG7LGk9YWUSNXGNrQ9mmhv3vEqbx/txs
https://minascan.io/mainnet/block/3NLE1GGYAp14ugaZPUVH2kyLM9GgVYhM6mrLiVrWvSUBP4Ka1q7W/txs

They both have same height, and was produced parallely, but only one ended up in main chain
Hmmm, we will discuss this with Mina team, but seems, that it can be to costly for us
No I got that part.
I didn’t understand the term because in my mind the predecessor is the parent, not the other way around.
So orphan block didn’t make sense in my mind.
But I don’t see how this pertains at all to your issue.
You just need to run your own node and listen
That’s it
Doesn’t an archive node give you what you want?
No, as I said they do not provide required data. Running our own node potentially can fix the issue, however we need to discuss it with Mina team, considering the cost
Archive node puts almost everything in a DB, you can’t recreate it from that?
Anyway just running your own node is probably best, should be trivial.
Look at protocol archive node uses to talk to node
Includes everything you need I think
Why do you need block hash, isn't state hash enough?

Is there any documentation about arhive node you mention? I found only this one(https://github.com/o1-labs/Archive-Node-API/blob/main/schema.graphql), and it have only queries for actions and events. Is there some other archive node?
I need at least something that lies in block A and can be proven in block B, which comes after block A and has a pseudo-random value
There is a protocol it uses to communicate with the node, which is undocumented I think.
But I still feel like archive node should have enough data for you.
is block hash "more random" than state hash for your use case?
Ok, I will check it
It is random enough, but how to prove it?
there is a precondition for `snarked_ledger_hash`

I can't use current snarked_ledger_hash. I need snarked_ledger_hash(or any other hash) for exact block. 
The main problem is to prove the value of hash in block A, given block B(that goes after block A)
you can use the witnessing method, where you witness the `snarked_ledger_hash` of the exact block you want
Can you describe this method a little bit more?

I meant the 2 steps process that you've discussed with @Las. Let's say you want to prove B1's `snarked_ledger_hash` in some future block B2.

In first step you send a txn after the B1 with an account update that sets a precondition to the B1's `snarked_ledger_hash` and somehow witnesses it. It can be by emitting an action, setting the state, or even being an empty account update with the precondition.

In second step in some future block B2, you have already witness of B1's `snarked_ledger_hash` somewhere in the ledger, you just have to prove it.
- in case of action, prove that it's part of the merkle list of action state
- in case of state, setting an account precondition to that state
- in case of an empty account update, prove that it's part of the merkle list of receipt chain hash

keep in mind that ledger hash can be manipulated by a block creator
Also make sure that the first txn has the fee payer's `valid_until` set, so that you don't end up paying for failed precondition.

The problem with this is how to prove it. Blockhash is technically easy to prove, because it is merkle list of blockbody hashes(as I understand). But Mina currently so not provide blockbodyhash in graphql. 

With state hash problem is the same - I can't find how to recreate it, so I can validate it on contract
I don't think block hash is technically easy to prove since you don't have a precondition for it. Why do you need to recreate it? You just have to prove that you've witnessed it.

For example, I need hash of block with slot 100. I can't guarantee, that my transaction will be in 100 slot. So for example I witness hash of slot 102. After this I need to recreate hash construction to get hash of block 100 from hash of block 102
You don't have a precondition for block hash, ie. you can't witness block hash of slot 102.

By hash i mean any hashLike data like SnarkedLedgerHash. 
However, isn't this.network.stakingEpochData.ledger.hash.getAndRequireEquals() is precondition for blockhash?
I don't think so

Regarding the recreation of `snarked_ledger_hash` for slot 102, you can recursively verify the block snarks that were provided in slots `100..102`. With new o1js support for side loaded verification key it might not be very hard.
Is there any documentation or example on how to do it?
I don't think so, that would be pretty advanced thing to do
Wait, is this just for randomness?
I assume it should be a pseudo random value revealed with an exact block.
Yes. If there is any suggestion on how to implement random, I will be more than happy to listen
All of this is way too complicated.
Just use staking ledger hash
It is not secure. We cannot use staking ledger hash of current block, because in this case random generator can pick block that he want
If it needs to be unknown you want to use a future staking ledger hash
Then just use future one
How
Just make your logic such that you get randomness in future tx?

That what I am trying to do. But for this to work, I should do exactly what I am asking in this thread.

Imagine I am at block 5. I want to get hash of block 100. I dont have guarantees that I would be able to call function at exactly 100 block. So I need to call function in block B, where B > 100. And using information from block B proof hash of block 100
Ahhh
